text: Stefan Marković (politician) (Zemun, Austrian Empire, 26 July 1804 - Vienna, Austrian Empire, 29 November 1864) was a Serbian politician.https://books.google.ca/books?id=yAmXBgAAQBAJ&pg;=PA180&dq;=Стефан+Марковић+(политичар)&hl;=en&sa;=X&ved;=0ahUKEwiKsM- IsJXkAhUEWq0KHbFoDcMQ6AEIKjAA#v=onepage&q;=Стефан%20Марковић%20(политичар)&f;=false He completed elementary school in his hometown in 1815, secondary school in Sremski Karlovci in 1821, studied at a university in Austria, and taught at a gymnasium in Koprivnica."Даница", Нови Сад 1864. In 1834 he came to live in Kragujevac, then the capital of Serbia. He was a member of the Government and the Secretary of the Prime Minister's Office from 1835; Director of the Prince's Office from 28 September 1837; Principal Secretary of the Privy Council from 1839; Member of the Council from 1842-1857; Minister of Justice and Minister of Education from 21 December 1854 to 29 May 1856; Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs from 29 May to 16 September 1856; Minister of Justice and Education from 16 September 1856 to 19 June 1857; and again Minister for Foreign Affairs from 19 June 1857 to 31 March 1858. He was nominated the first member of the Društvo srbske slovesnosti (Society Of Serbian Letters: forerunner of the Serbian Royal Academy) on 27 May 1842; he also held the post of the President of Društvo srbske slovesnosti (DSS) from 27 December 1854 until 19 June 1857. With the return to power of Prince Miloš Obrenović, Marković, knowing that his political career was over, left the country in 1858 never to return.
